title-group.article-title: Facile synthesis of highly conductive PPy/graphene nanosheet /Gd3+ composites

article-meta.aff: 1College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwest Normal University, Lanzhou, China
2Experiment Center of Northwest University for Nationalities, Lanzhou, China
3State Key Laboratory of Solidification Processing, Northwestern Polytechnical University, Xi’an, China

author-notes.corresp: Zunli Mo, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwest Normal University, Lanzhou 730070, China. Email: mozl@163.com

abstract.p: Highly conductive PPy/graphene nanosheet and PPy/graphene nanosheet/Gd3+ composites were prepared via in-situ polymerization with p-toluenesulfonic acid as a dopant and FeCl3 as an oxidant. The effects of graphene nanosheet obtained by two different synthetic methods and Gd3+ on the electrical conductivity of the composites were investigated. The results showed that the graphene nanosheet as a filler had an effect on the conductivity of PPy/graphene nanosheet similar to PPy/graphene nanosheet/Gd3+ composites, which played an important role in forming a conducting network in PPy matrix. Thermal gravimetric analysis demonstrated an improved thermal stability of PPy in the PPy/graphene nanosheet/Gd3+ composites. The microstructures of PPy/graphene nanosheet/Gd3+ were characterized by scanning electron microscope and transmission electron microscope examinations.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Graphite is one of the widely studied and inexpensive carbon fillers 1,2 due to its unique properties such as good conductivity, better adsorption capability and low cost in comparison with other fillers. 3,4 The excellent properties may be relevant to the nanoscale if graphite can be exfoliated into nanosheet. 5 Graphene, namely few- and single-layer graphene, is defined as a true two-dimensional material, which has initiated enormous scientific activities from both the experimental and theoretical scientific communities due to its extraordinary electrical, thermal, mechanical properties and so on. 6,7 These unique features make graphene emerging as a new class of fascinating materials that can be widely used in sensors, 8 supercapacitors 9 and transparent conducting films. 10 Recently, graphene has been used as the conducting filler for making conducting polymer composites because graphene is responsible for the low percolation threshold and highly electrical conductivity. 11,12

Conducting polymer composites are formed by dispersing different functional fillers into a polymer matrix and have attracted many researchers to explore their potential applications as high-performance materials. The electrically conducting polymers such as polypyrrole (PPy) are particularly promising owing to their highly electrical conductivity, corrosion performance, ease of low cost synthesis and environmental stability. 13,14 However, the disadvantages of PPy can not be ignored, such as not easily soluble in common organic solvents, processing difficulties and relatively low conductivity, which has limited the application of PPy in practice. 15 In order to improve the properties of PPy, a series of conducting PPy composites were prepared by using graphite/graphene as the conducting filler to explore their potential applications as high-performance materials. 16 Meanwhile, a series of PPy composites were reported by using metal/metallic oxide as the conducting filler, such as silver (Ag), 17 platinum-ruthenium (Pt–Ru), 18 tungsten oxide (WO3), 19 and manganese dioxide (MnO2). 20 The results showed that the conductivity and mechanical properties of PPy are significantly improved. Literary survey reveals that there is a dearth of reports on graphene achieved by using two different synthetic methods (as the conductive filler) having an effect on the conductivity of polymer composites and three-phase highly electrical conductivity composites, especially in the case of PPy/graphene nanosheet/rare earth ions composites.

This research showed that GNSB (graphene nanosheet obtained by using ortho-dichlorobenzene as ultrasonic media to exfoliate expanded graphite.) and GNSH (graphene nanosheet obtained by reduced from graphene oxide with hydrazine hydrate.) had similar effect on the conductivity of PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH. The microstructures and properties of PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH composites through introduction of Gd3+ have also been investigated.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: The graphite used for preparing graphite nanosheet was expandable graphite, provided by Shandong Qingdao Graphite Company (China). Graphite powder was obtained from Tianjin SiTong Chemical Plant. The pyrrole monomer (Py), purchased from Shanghai Chemical Company (China), was purified by vapor distillation before use. The gadolinium chloride, hydrazine hydrate, hydrogen peroxide, potassium permanganate, sulfuric acid, sodium nitrate, ferric chloride crystals (FeCl3·6H2O), polyethylene glycol 400 (PEG-400), p-toluenesulfonic acid (p-TSA) and ortho-dichlorobenzene at analytical reagent grade were obtained from Shanghai Chemical Company (China) and used as received.

sec.title: Preparation of graphene nanosheet (GNSB)
sec.p: The expanded graphite was prepared according to previous literature. 21 The GNSB was prepared using ortho-dichlorobenzene as ultrasonic media. 22 The synthetic process was as follows: the expanded graphite was immersed in ortho-dichlorobenzene and subjected to powdering in an ultrasonic bath at 80 W for 0.5 h, and then filtered and washed with enough ethyl alcohol and deionized water. The resulting suspension was dried in the vacuum oven at 50°C for 24 h to obtain GNSB.

sec.title: Preparation of graphene nanosheet (GNSH)
sec.p: Graphene nanosheet (GNSH) was reduced from graphene oxide (graphene oxide was produced by Hummers’ method, 23,24 with hydrazine hydrate according to the literature. 25 In a typical procedure, graphene oxide (GO) (100 mg) was loaded in a 250 mL round-bottom flask and then water (100 mL) was added, yielding an inhomogeneous yellow-brown dispersion. This dispersion was sonicated until it became clear with no visible particulate matter. Hydrazine hydrate (1.00 mL, 32.1 mmol) was then added and the solution heated in an oil bath at 100°C under a water-cooled condenser for 24 h over which the reduced GO gradually precipitated out as a black solid. This product was isolated by filtration over microporous membrane, washed copiously with water (5 × 100 mL) and methanol (5 × 100 mL), and dried on the funnel under a continuous air flow through the solid product cake.

sec.title: In-situ polymerization to prepare PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH composites
sec.p: The PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH composites were prepared via in-situ oxidative polymerization of pyrrole monomer in the presence of GNSB or GNSH. The synthetic process was as follows: 1 mL PEG-400, 7.22 mmol pyrrole and a certain amount of GNSB or GNSH were mixed into 6 mL C2H5OH and the mixture was sonicated for about 2 h at room temperature. Then a dark gray colloidal system was obtained. After stirring for 15 min at 0∼5°C, 2 mmol p-TSA was injected into the above mixture and stirred for 20 min. Finally, 50 mL of 0.34 mol L−1 FeCl3·6H2O aqueous solution (FeCl3/pyrrole = 2.35 : 1 molar ratio) was dropped into the reactor and a rapid oxidation occurred. The resulted suspension was stirred at 0∼5°C for 2 h. The polymerization was allowed to proceed for 22 h at room temperature with a continuous stirring. The product obtained was then filtered and washed with deionized water and ethanol, and dried at 50°C in vacuum for 24 h.

sec.title: Preparation of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites
sec.p: For the preparation of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites, 1 mL PEG-400, 7.22 mmol pyrrole, a certain amount of GNSB (or GNSH) and GdCl3 were mixed into 6 mL C2H5OH and the mixture was sonicated for about 2 h at room temperature. The remaining synthetic steps are similar with that of PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH composites. The resulting composites were designated as PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites.

sec.title: Characterization
sec.p: A scanning electron microscope (SEM; Hitachi, Japan, JEOL, JSM-6330F) was used to observe the morphologies of the composites. Prior to the characterization, the specimen were coated with a very thin layer of gold atoms. A transmission electron microscope (TEM; JEOL100CX-II model) was run at 100 kV accelerated voltage to observe the morphologies. The observations were carried out after retrieving the slices onto Cu grids. Fourier-transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) of the samples in KBr pellets were recorded on an EQUINOX55 FT-IR spectrometer (Bruker). The weight loss temperatures of the composites were determined with a Perkin-Elmer thermogravimetric analyzer (TGDTA; model SSC-5200) from 25 to 800°C under nitrogen atmosphere (10°C min−1). The electrical conductivity measurements were made by the conventional four-point probes resistivity measurement system (china model RTS-B) on pressed pellets of composite prepared at room temperature (25°C).

sec.title: The micrographs of composites
sec.p: For comparison, graphene was prepared by two different synthetic methods as described above. First, it was found that the yield of the graphene nanosheet was relatively low by using alcohol or acetone as ultrasonic media, sonication also needed a long time and the graphene nanosheet was relatively thick. 21,26,27 So, in order to reduce the thickness of the graphene and improve its yield, ortho-dichlorobenzene is chosen to quickly exfoliate expanded graphite as an ultrasonic media. Using this approach the large sized GNSB can be produced. The level of exfoliation of the expanded graphite was characterized by TEM as shown in Figure 1(a). The TEM image of GNSB revealed the presence of a few single-layer graphene layers while some of GNSB was observed with a few layers. But the GNSH obtained by being reduced GO with hydrazine hydrate was almost totally composed of few- and single-layer graphene (Figure 1(b)).

caption.p: TEM micrograph of: (a) GNSB and (b) GNSH.

sec.p: Figure 2 shows the FT-IR spectra of the PPy, PPy/GNSH, PPy/GNSB/Gd3+, PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ and GNSH. Pure PPy shows the peak locations at 1523 and 1428 cm−1, which were due to C=C and C–N stretching, respectively. The band at 1385 cm−1 was attributed to C–H vibrations. The peak at 1170 cm−1 was attributed to C–C stretching. The band at 1042 cm−1 was due to in-plane deformation of the C–H bond and N–H bond of the pyrrole ring. The band at 925 cm−1 was assigned to the C–C out-of-phase deformation vibration. 19 In the sample graphene, the peak at about 1640 cm−1 was attributed to the skeletal vibration of the graphene sheets. 28 As seen in Figure 2, in a comparison with the pure PPy, it was clearly observed that the spectra of PPy/GNSH, PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ had no obvious difference except that they showed peak shifts from 1170 to 1163 cm−1 and 1042 to 1038 cm−1 when GNSB or GNSH was introduced into the synthesis process of PPy, which might be ascribed to the conjugate effect such as π–π stacking between the PPy backbone and graphene. 29

caption.p: FT-IR spectra of: (a) pure PPy; (b) PPy/GNSH; (c), PPy/GNSB/Gd; (d), PPy/GNSH/Gd; and (e) GNSH.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the SEM microstructures of PPy (Figure 3(a)), PPy/GNSB (Figure 3(b)), PPy/GNSH (Figure 3(c)) PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ (Figure 3(d)) and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ (Figure 3(e)), respectively. From Figures 3(b), (c), (d) and (e), it is clearly observed that partially PPy were evenly distributed on the surface of the GNSB or GNSH layers, whereas others seem embedded into the GNSB or GNSH layers, which may improve the effective contact between the GNSB or GNSH layers and PPy. Our results are very similar to Lee findings. 30 However, compared with the PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH, SEM microstructures of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ had no obvious difference. Because Gd3+ ions were introduced to the composites of PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH, rather than Gd nanoparticles, the morphology of Gd3+ ions in the SEM of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ could not be observed.

caption.p: SEM of: (a) PPy; (b), PPy/GNSB; (c), PPy/GNSH; (d), PPy/GNSB/Gd3+; and (e) PPy/GNSH/Gd3+.

sec.p: Figure 4 shows TEM micrographs of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ (Figure 4(a)) and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ (Figure 4(b)). From Figure 4(a) and (b), it can be clearly seen that PPy was covered with GNSB and GNSH, which is quite consistent with SEM observations.

caption.p: TEM of: (a) PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and (b) PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites.

sec.title: Conductivity characteristics
sec.p: Highly conductive pure PPy was synthesized by using p-TSA as a dopant and FeCl3 as an oxidizing agent at room temperature, while also adding a certain amount of PEG-400. By this method, pure PPy possessed more high conductivities (2.0 S cm−1) than the reports of other researchers. Conductivities of PPy showed 7.3 × 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature using cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) as a surfactant and ammonium persulfate (APS) as an oxidizing agent; 31 about 0.312 S cm−1 at 314 and 219.6 K by using p-TSA as a dopant and APS as an oxidizing agent; 32 and 0.031 S cm−1 at 300 K by using FeCl3 as an oxidizing agent. 33 So, the species of the acid media and oxidant have a tremendous effect on conjugated structure, size and conductivity of the PPy nanoparticles. Therefore, the introduction of PEG-400, using p-TSA as a dopant and FeCl3 as an oxidizing agent may be the appropriate choice in the synthesis of highly conductive PPy and PPy composites.

From Figure 5, it can be easily observed that the conductivity of PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH composites in PPy matrix could be rapidly increased in comparison with pure PPy as the amount of GNSB and GNSH increased. The conductivity values of PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH, namely 6.76 and 6.80 S cm−1, respectively, which were much greater than the pure PPy, occurred with 1 wt.% GNSB and GNSH at room temperature.

caption.p: The conductivity of PPy/GNSB and PPy/GNSH composites with GNSB and GNSH loading of 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 4 wt.%, respectively.

sec.p: Figure 6 shows the variation of conductivity for PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites with different amounts of Gd3+. Keeping the GNSB and GNSH amounts of 1 wt.%, the conductivity of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ was increased as the amount of Gd3+ increased. However, it is interesting that the conductivity decreased as the Gd3+ loading increased beyond 3 wt.%, which can be ascribed to the percolation threshold of the composites. From Figure 6, it can be seen that the improvement in the conductivity of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites was not very significant through the introduction of Gd3+, because the Gd3+ ions were introduced, rather than nanoparticles of Gd.

caption.p: The conductivity of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites with Gd3+ loading of 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 wt.%, respectively.

sec.p: The augmentation of the high electrical conductivity of composites can be ascribed to the following reasons: first, GNSB and GNSH have a layered structure similar to natural flake graphite with large interlayer spacing and high specific surface area. 11 Therefore, PPy can be intercalated into the interlayer space of GNSB and GNSH, and the effective and close contact between the GNSB or GNSH layer and PPy is then expected to be improved by the large van der Waal’s force of attraction between the GNSB or GNSH basal plane and the π-conjugated PPy. 16,24 Secondly, the introduction of PEG-400 can make PPy possess a longer π-conjugated chain which could benefit pure PPy and composites by causing them to have higher electrical conductivity. Based on the above two reasons, it was concluded that GNSB or GNSH and Gd3+ could promote the formation of electrically conductive networks in the PPy matrix.

sec.title: Thermal stability
sec.p: Figure 7 shows the thermal stability of pure PPy (a), PPy/GNSH (b), PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ (c), PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ (d) and GNSH (e). The GNSH showed high thermal stability compared with pure PPy, PPy/GNSH, PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSB/Gd3+. All the samples were observed to exhibit two distinct weight loss stages. The steady weight loss at temperatures lower than 310°C could be attributed to the evaporation of moisture and solvent residue in the samples. The major loss at temperatures higher than 270°C was attributed to the decomposition of PPy. The results were similar to the reports of other researchers. 18,33,34 With the addition of GNSH, the degradation temperature of PPy (270°C) increased to 310°C for the PPy/GNSH with the GNSH loading of 1 wt.%. However, with the addition of GNSB (or GNSH) and Gd3+, the degradation temperatures of PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ (with a nanoparticle loading of 1 wt.% (GNSH) and 6 wt.% (Gd3+)) and PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ (with a nanoparticle loading of 1 wt.% (GNSB) and 6 wt.% (Gd3+)) composites was not significantly improved. The TGA curve of PPy exhibited about 90% weight loss in the temperature scale of 270 to 673°C and 5% weight residual at 800°C. However, the change of weight in PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composite was similar to the PPy/GNSB/Gd3+. The composites of PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ still kept about 20.7 and 24.3% residual weight at 673°C, respectively, indicating excellent thermal stability, but the PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ composites also showed dramatic mass losses in the temperature range 270 to 740°C, mainly due to the decompositions of PPy components. The retarding effect of the graphene and Gd3+ also contributed to the increased decomposition temperature, which was observed in polypyrrole/sulfonated graphene composite film 12 and polyaniline/graphite composites. 35

caption.p: TGA curves of: (a) pure PPy; (b), PPy/GNSH; (c), PPy/GNSH/Gd3+; (d), PPy/GNSB/Gd3+; (e) GNSH.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The PPy/GNSB, PPy/GNSH, PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites have been successfully prepared by in-situ polymerization and showed a obvious increase of electrical conductivity compared with pure PPy. Systematic studies on the electrical conductivity of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites revealed that the GNSB (or GNSH) and Gd3+ may be simultaneously contributed to the increase in the conductivity of PPy/GNSB/Gd3+ and PPy/GNSH/Gd3+ composites. From thermogravimetric analysis, the introduction of GNSB (or GNSH) and Gd3+ exhibited a beneficial effect on the thermal stability of pure PPy. The understanding of such information will be very helpful for designing, fabricating and developing further new composite materials based on conductive PPy. In future studies, a series of PPy/graphene/rare earth ions composites will be researched as photoelectrical materials.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The authors would like to acknowledge the financial support from the Natural Science Foundation of Gansu Province (0803RJZA009; 1010RJZA023) and the funding from the State Key Laboratory of Solidification Processing in NWPU (SKLSP201011); Key Laboratory of Eco-Environment-Related Polymer Materials, Ministry of Education of China; Key Laboratory of Polymer Materials of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Northwest Normal University, Lanzhou, P. R. China.
